results.title: View from the typewriter
results.creator_credit: Robert Duncan, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A compilation of excerpts from National Film Board of Canada documentaries that deal with Canadian writers and their sense of place. Featuring readings from the works of Hugh MacLennan, W.O. Mitchell, Jack Hodges, Farley Mowat, Margaret Laurence, Earle Birney, Malcolm Lowry, Leonard Cohen, Margaret Atwood and Milton Acorn, the documentary examines how Canadian writers have attempted to make sense of a landscape and a geography that traverses huge differences of scale, topography and climate. The readings are powerful, including Richard Burton reading from Lowry’s work, and though specific to the Canadian experience, the film is also relevant to Australian writing about extremes of location. Just like English speaking Canadians, our writing too grapples with making sense of a country and terrain which encompasses the duality of being both “new” and ancient.

results.title: Vietnam: the war that divided America
results.creator_credit: Eve Cotton, Matthew M. Howe and Associated Press
results.brief_description: The Vietnam War was the longest lasting conflict in American history and has a continuing legacy in regards to policy decisions and American society today. Presented in four sections (Early involvement; U.S. Escalation; Reaction at home; Aftershocks), this short documentary provides a general overview from French occupation to the signing of the Paris Peace Treaty in 1973. Cover areas such as; the French Indo-China war, the Battle of Dien Bien Phu, formation of the NLF and Viet Cong, the overthrow of South Vietnam President Ngo Dinn Diem, the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, opposition in America towards President Johnson and the national draft, the Tet Offensive, and the mass migration of Vietnamese following 30 years of fighting. A program guide accompanies the video.

results.title: Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War. - Volume 4.
results.creator_credit: Don North, Ian Macleod, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions
results.brief_description: Siege - covers the 77-day siege of Khe Sahn and the explosion of the Tet Offensive, and how these battles intensified the anti-war sentiment in the U.S. “Frontline America” - continues the examination of American dissent, giving an overview of President Nixon’s determination to obtain peace through pressure.

results.title: Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War. - Volume 3.
results.creator_credit: Don North, Ian Macleod, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions
results.brief_description: The Trail - explores the Ho Chi Minh Trail, a 1500 mile system of mountain paths that was the lifeline for North Vietnam. “Firepower” covers the American strategy to stop the war through air power, and studies U.S. military operations at the period of maximum troop involvement.

results.title: Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: Don North, Ian Macleod, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions
results.brief_description: Days of Decision - examines the gradual falling out of Washington and Saigon, and President Johnson’s crucial decision to send combat troops into South Vietnam. “Uneasy Allies” - looks at the effects, both political and cultural, that Americans have on the country that they are inhabiting.

results.title: Sequence and story
results.creator_credit: Don White, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
In this film a group of children manipulate reality using a series of photographs of their own activities. As they lay out the photos in different sequences, the story of their day changes. Simple, realistic dialogue and a combination of live action and still photographs capture the viewer’s imagination.
Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Sentences and paragraphs
results.creator_credit: John Moss and Video Education Australasia
results.brief_description: Celebrated author Margaret Clark discusses this most fundamental topic. Margaret reads from one of her books to illustrate key points. Also helping to provide interest in what can be perceived as a boring topic, is a leading Melbourne comedian and mime artist, Richard Jones. The program is funny, highly informative and definitely not boring! Suitable for Primary-Lower Secondary level students.

results.title: Werckmeister harmonies. Damnation = Werckmeister harmoniak. Karhozat
results.creator_credit: Bela Tarr, Franz Goess, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Josef Marx, Miklos Szita, Paul Saadoun, 13 Productions, Goess Films, Magyar Filmintezet, Magyar Televizio, Mokep and Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion
results.brief_description: Werckmeister harmonies: Haunting and atmospheric, this slow-moving narrative filmed in stark black and white reflects the harsh political environment that is Eastern Europe. The main character, Jancos (Lars Rudolph), a visionary and an outsider is drawn to the arrival in his bleak provincial town on the Hungarian plains, of a circus featuring the stuffed carcass of a massive dead whale and a mysterious, somewhat sinister figure called “The Prince”. What follows this arrival into this already economically depressed village is quite disturbing. Using long and lingering shots, the images create nuances and subtleties that make “Werckmeister harmonies” an intriguing and beautiful film. Cast also includes Peter Fitz, Hanna Schygulla. Based on “The Melancholy of Resistance” by Laszlo Krasznahorkai. “Damnation”: Featuring Bela Tarr’s renowned long takes and bleak black and white images, this story follows Karrer (Miklos B. Szekely), a sullen and listless man obsessed with a married woman (Vali Kerekes) who sings at a local bar, the Titanik. Betrayal and conflict eventually lead to despair for Karrer and alienation from those around him. Extremely slow, beautifully photographed and quite depressing but definitely compelling. Cast also includes Gyula Pauer, Gyorgy Cserhalmi. A collaboration with writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bela Tarr, Franz Goess, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Josef Marx, Miklos Szita, Paul Saadoun, 13 Productions, Goess Films, Magyar Filmintezet, Magyar Televizio, Mokep and Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion

results.title: Tobacco wars
results.creator_credit: Derek Jones, Ros Franey and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: While the sale of cigarettes has decreased significantly on the Western market, worldwide consumption of cigarettes has increased markedly since the push of tobacco giants R.J. Reynolds and Philip Morris to export to Asia. Presented by the British current affairs team at “First Tuesday,” this program looks at the human cost of cigarette smoking and the war that is being waged between health and trade. Narrator Michael Crocker explains the relationship between advertising in Asia, cigarette sales and the incidence of cancer, brand stretching to bypass advertising bans and the role of government heavy weights in lobbying on behalf of the tobacco industry. Features interviews with cigarette models Janet Sackman and Wayne (Marlboro Man) McLaren, both of whom have earned notoriety for their role in cigarette advertising as well as cancer attributed to their nicotine addiction. Presented by Olivia O’Leary.

results.title: Wings to Guatemala
results.creator_credit: Jean Oser, Stanley Toogood and International Film Productions
results.brief_description: A brief history of Guatemala is presented. The descendents of the Mayan Indians are shown on the shores of Lake Atillan, living a life that is largely based on ancient tradition. They work for six days on Chichicastenango to sell their goods and workshop their old Mayan gods on the steps on the church. Scenes are included of the modern city of Guatemala and the luxurious resorts set among the ruins of the past. The fondness of the people for music and traditional dancing is shown.
